messages.page_content: We just came down this morning to tell the City Council thank you for putting that ballot initiative on the ballot on Saturday.
And I'd like them to tell you that. Ladies and gentlemen, we understand the difficulties
that a lot of them have been going through. And I just want to again, my heartfelt thanks to the entire City Council
for their opportunity to allow us to be able to do this.
You know, going forward, we thank the Mayor for what she's done for the New Orleans Council on Aging and the elderly community.
But hopefully we'll be able to do more. And we understand, we know that once this millage passes that there's companion legislation.
And we know through your wisdom that you all will put that together. And we just want to say thank you.
This has been a struggle for a number of years. All of you up there know that.
And what we're trying to do is to have individuals to age in place. And that's about it. So again, thank you very much.
Thank you.
Howard, Howard, thank you. Thank you for saying that. And folks, thank you all for coming this morning just to say thank you.
You know, that doesn't happen very often in City Council.
Very rarely do people come in here and say thank you. So I really want to thank you all for doing that.
And thank you for your years of sacrifice and toil to this community.
I know there are some of you who are raising your children's kids.
There are some of you who are improving communities by showing them ways that worked in the past that have people don't look at it anymore.
And you all have paid more taxes than anybody else just by the nature of years of being here.
You all have paid more dues when it was far harder to live in this city.
And I say that as an African American, things weren't always as good as they are now.
Things have improved, but they have improved because of the work and the toil of you all. So thank you.
Madam Clerk.
Roll call. Councilmember Wynn present. Councilmember Brissette present. Councilmember Williams present. Councilmember Moreno present.
Councilmember Gisses and Palmer present. Councilmember Banks present. Councilmember Garuso present.
We have seven members. We have a core.
Madam Clerk, thank you. We will have the invocation by Bishop Imram Chidaka, followed by the Pledge of Allegiance by Councilmember Brissette.
And the national anthem by our very own Angela Sarker.
Father God, we come this morning.
First of all, Father said thank you for waking us up this morning.
We thank you for the great mayor of this Christian city, LaToya Cottrell.
Father God, we thank you for the city councilmen and the city councilwomen.
And they sit on the cabinet, Father, and they delegate and orchestrate laws, rules and regulations. What must we do, Father?
Then we thank you for all the first response. The firefighters, EMS. Father, we thank you for the policemen.
Everyone that contributed, we become a team to make sure this becomes a great city and continues to be a great state.
Bless everyone here that's present this morning, Father God.
Every nationality, every ethnic group, Father, every faith, Jew, Buddhism, Hinduism, Father, Muslim, we're all your children, Father.
Father, we ask right now in your name, Father, to continue to help us to do those things which is well pleasing in your sight.
We pray in your name. Amen.
Amen.
Amen. And thank you, Bishop. It was an honor to meet our lovely mother yesterday.
It was an honor.
God bless you.
Thank you.
With God, with the United States of America, and with the Republic, we say,
One nation, with God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.
Oh, say, can you see, by the dawn's early light,
What so proudly we hailed at the twilight's last gleaming,
Whose broad stripes and bright stars through the perilous fight,
O'er the ramparts we watched, were so gallantly streaming?
And the rocket's red glare, the bombs bursting in air,
Gave proof through the night that our flag was still there.
Oh, say, does that star-spangled banner yet wave,
O'er the land of the free and the home of the brave?
All right, Miss Sorkin. All right, Miss Sorkin. You're hired. You're hired.
We have the special orders of business.
The first order of business is a presentation.
French Quarter Festival, Emily Marato, President and CEO of French Quarter Festibles, Inc. and Ayo Scott Artis.
Representatives from the French Quarter Festival will be promoting their annual festival.
Yes, my coffee. I'm sorry.
All right, Emily, why don't you all come down here and sit at the table.
All right, everybody, it's getting to be our favorite time of the year.
Yes, it is.
Which is our festival time. And we've got two people here from my personally favorite festival, which is French Quarter Festival.
And the reason I love it so much is that it's free.
And it's a great way for everybody in our city, from every part of our city, to come and enjoy what makes New Orleans so special.
And it's also wonderful to bring your kids out, to bring your family members out and just have a wonderful day.
And for those of you who don't know, this year, French Quarter Fest is celebrating their 36th anniversary.
It started back in 1984, if we all remember, back to following the World's Fair.
And there'll be more than 20 stages spread throughout the French Quarter with every type of music.
And we have Emily here to talk a little bit more about that.
They are also one of my favorite festivals because of their emphasis on locals and hiring local talent, local musicians, local artists, local food vendors.
And so with that, I would love to pass it over to Emily Madero and just introduce yourself and Mr. Scott and give us the headliner.
Wonderful. Well, thank you, Councilmember Palmer, for inviting me here today.
What an inspirational way to spend the morning.
Congratulations to all the women and men who are honored this morning.
And thank you to the Council for your support and leadership every single day.
So we are building a French Quarter Festival on Monday, and I never give up an opportunity to come talk about the event.
So I.O. and I are going to give you a little sneak preview from the Insider.
And the first thing that I want to talk about is just to remind everybody, I know that the Council here,
you are all really important partners in what we do.
But some of you may or may not know that the festival is produced by a nonprofit.
And I think that's really important to understand what our purpose is and how we're grounded.
We are an independent nonprofit that was founded 36 years ago today, really to celebrate our unique local culture and specifically to drive economic opportunity and impact in the Vous Carre.
And 36 years later, that mission and that purpose still rings true.
Of course, we produce French Quarter Festival, but we also can't wait to see you in August for Satchmo Summerfest,
which is another incredible gem of the city and Christmas, New Orleans style.
So I'm here today to talk about French Quarter Festival, which, if you didn't know, is the largest showcase of Louisiana music and culture in the entire world.
And what better way to celebrate it than taking over the French Quarter.
As I said, we have a dual mission to celebrate and showcase our culture and also to drive economic impact.
And we're really proud that the work that we do results in $196 million worth of economic impact.
And we support 2,200 jobs full time and part time.
We do that because we throw a really good party and 700,000 people come annually to celebrate French Quarter Festival.
We have about 50% local guests.
We continue to be a local's favorite and that's because of our emphasis on our local music.
But we also, the word has gotten out and we do have some visitors who help fill hotel rooms and go to restaurants and enjoy the festival.
Another thing that I'm really proud of is over the 300 acts that we book throughout the four days, we hire 1,700 musicians.
And this event has grown really organically throughout the years.
It used to be that we used to have to ask musicians to volunteer their time.
Something that we're working really hard to do right now is to continue to grow our musicians fund every year.
So we are really proud that we pay all of our musicians above union rates.
Thank you to the council and to Councilman Williams.
You support us through the Harris Community grant every year.
Any of you can go to the festival and use the tip jars.
100% of those funds go directly to our musicians and we're really excited to be able to showcase them because that's what this event is all about.
Of course we couldn't do it without the 1,500 volunteers who help us actually produce and run the festival.
And what would a festival be without the food that we love so much?
So you can come out and you can taste everything from fine dining at Galatois or you can have Miss Linda's Yakimane.
We call it fine dining to food truck.
All of those chefs are really important to our culinary fabric that we all love and enjoy so much here in New Orleans.
We're going to showcase 23 stages over four days for one incredible New Orleans experience.
So again we talked a little bit about the musicians and our economic impact.
I'm really proud that $57 million of that economic impact directly is an earnings for New Orleans area residents.
And the city is benefiting.
Part of our mission is bringing in important tax dollars.
So what's new?
We want to give you a little bit of an insider's scoop.
So this year, of course, the music and the food come first for our guest experience and that's why we run this event.
But every year we strive to improve our guest experience and it's really important to our organization to continue to be good stewards.
And good organizations.
So this year we're really excited to be able to offer recycling at all of our major sites.
That may not seem like rocket science, but it's something as a non-profit.
You know, we work with seven different vendors as it is to deal with sanitation.
It's incredibly expensive for a free event.
The economics are completely upside down and backwards.
The more people we have, the more expensive it is to run.
But we think that it's very important to our mission in terms of instilling an increased sense of pride in our city.
And it's the right thing to do in terms of making sure that we're taking care of our environment and our good stewards.
So I have to thank, this is, I'm going to coin it, the Palmer Cup.
I got on the phone with Councilmember Palmer about six months ago and I was talking about recycling and seeing how we might be able to work with the city.
Of course we're going to bring recycling to all of our major festival sites.
I hope someday that we can extend that into the French Quarter neighborhood and offer recycling all throughout the neighborhood.

I would love to be able to use our platform as a way to sort of promote recycling from leveraging sort of a cultural asset that's part of the thing that we need to do in terms of educating our citizens.
And I said, you know, how are we going to pay for $50,000 worth of recycling?
And she said, well, what about using a cup?
So we are going to roll out a reusable cup.
We're really proud to showcase Corey Henry and Chief Juan Pardo on that cup.
You'll see their images on our promotion poster.
And this does two great things.
One, it promotes the reduction of single-use products in the festival.
And it also is going to help pay for that recycling.
So thank you for your wonderful ideas.
We're going to start small.
Of course, as you can imagine, rolling this out across a huge festival, the sanitation and logistics is infinitely complicated.
So we're going to start small with our beer cups and hopefully be able to expand this in the future.
And we hope to divert four tons of trash from landfills.
The other thing we want to do is make sure to make strides in making our festival accessible.
We love that it's free.
We want to be welcoming to everybody here in New Orleans that you can come and enjoy the festival,
no matter if you want to go enjoy some traditional jazz on Royal Street,
or you like the big crowds on the river, or you want to spend some time in the kids tent.
But navigating that can be difficult and overwhelming.
So we have added some ADA accessible platforms in some of our largest sites.
We are including an ADA information tent, which has things like Braille brochures and a map of all the ADA services.
And the last thing is we are partnering with Culture Cities.
So they are an organization that provides services for folks that have sensory needs.
We have a mobile sensory unit and sensory bags for children that may be on the spectrum or adults with PTSD
for whom big crowds and loud noises can be overwhelming.
We have trained our staff and are providing resources to make sure that they can come out and enjoy Louisiana culture
in a way that's safe and inclusive.
So the reason why we are here is really to talk about the music.
As I mentioned, we have 300 performances, 48 debuts.
We have folks that we love to see every year, like Ms. Irma Thomas, the sole queen of New Orleans.
But part of our mission is also finding those up and coming artists
and providing them a platform to showcase their talents.
So you can come see it across 23 stages.
We have free dance lessons, whether they are swing lessons to Cajun Zydeco.
And we are doing something new this year, bringing an expanded evening concert series onto the Chevron stage in Bienville Triangle.
So we are bringing more of our headliners into the French Quarter neighborhood.
It's going to be a great way to enjoy the show.
I had to give a little bit of a plug because there are some special events that may not be very well known.
And the Let Them Talk stage is an incredible opportunity to hear directly from the artists about their life and their inspiration.
So you should all check out the Let Them Talk stage that's over the weekend at the New Orleans Jazz Museum at The Mint.
And of course, the Chevron STEMZone.
You can learn all about the world.
They are going to be covering seven continents and the galaxy.
And we work with partners throughout the city to come bring really exciting and interactive activities for kids.
So now I'm going to hand it over to Ayo Scott.
We are so incredibly honored to have the opportunity to work with him, not only for French Quarter Festival, but for Satchmo Summerfest.
We're trying something really new.
And it's been an absolute pleasure and an inspiration to work with you, Ayo.
Thank you.
I want to thank the council and the city.
I want to thank Emily and the staff over at French Quarterfest for giving me the opportunity.
But also the honor of being able to capture a New Orleans legend like Irma Thomas in this year's poster.
It's really a blessing to be able to have an opportunity like that and to be a part of something like the festival culture that this city provides,
allowing a person to make a living as an artist is a beautiful thing.
And I'm grateful for that opportunity.
I just want to say thank you.
Thanks, Ayo.
So finally, there's a lot of fun things that we're thrilled to talk about.
And most importantly, it truly does take a village, as you know, to make this event happen.
And I want to thank the council and the city.
We work with you throughout the year to make sure that we are creating a safe and fun event,
taking into consideration the needs of our attendees, our neighborhood, the city.
We are so grateful for NOPD, NOFD, NOEMS, who we hire to help us keep the event safe.
We also work with Homeland Security, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
Last year we had a little bit of a rainout, and I could not have been more grateful for the council of all of these folks who made that decision to ensure the safety of our attendees really easy.
We also coordinate with RTA and make sure that the buses and the ferries and all the public modes of transportation are accessible, and we're really grateful for that.
We rely on strategic partnerships, the French Market Corporation, who we work very closely with, and all of our landowners.
French Market Corporation hosts two stages, so you can come see them.
But we are thrilled to have a brand new stage, which is going to be debuting on the brand new Moonwalk extension.
So you can come see traditional jazz on the Mississippi River, which is going to be a beautiful experience with dancing at dusk and dance lessons.
And finally, we rely very heavily on a city ordinance which helps to ensure that we have a clean zone, which is critical to ensuring the safety and security of the event.
As I said, we are so integrated with city services that we want to make sure that we are able to work with them.
And this is an incredibly important thing.
We thank you for your help in guiding us through that process and ensuring that we are producing an event that is going to be successful and also safe for all of our attendees.
So finally, I'd like to invite to you, we are going to be kicking off our festival on April 11th.
Coming up very shortly, as I said, we're starting to build stages next Monday.
We love our tradition on Thursday morning at 10 a.m.
We'll be lining up on Bourbon Street for a parade into Jackson Square while we have our opening ceremony.
So please come and join us.
Thank you so much for your continued leadership and support.
And we're looking forward to it.
Well, thank you, Emily.
Palmer Cup sounds much better than Palmer Band.
So I'm really excited about that.
But Councilmember Williams.
Let me just first say I am a huge fan of your work, just your skill and artisanry, but your subject matter, I just think is just amazing.
So and that post is phenomenal.
And I can't wait to put it up somewhere in my house.
Emily, you know, I tell you this every time we talk, I don't know how you do it.
I really don't know how this vessel was free.
It's amazing.
It is better than things people charge hundreds of dollars for in other places.
And I mean, I'm amazed.
I'm amazed.
And then to add that recycling component, you know, that that is that's a big deal.
It's something that we should be, frankly, more innovative of in as a city.
I mean, I think about glass and bottles and what we're not doing.
And for your festival to take that on, knowing that it's going to cost and then it'd be ingenious enough to figure out a way to offset that cost with the cups with my man Corey Henry on it.
I think it's amazing.
Well done.
And then to up the ante so that folks who may be on the autism spectrum can still enjoy this phenomenal event, I think, is something that I hope other festivals are taking notice of.
Because you're delivering what is uniquely ours to people who have special needs.
And I think that's just fascinating that you that you took the time and attention to focus on delivering that so they can enjoy it as well.
This I take my hat off to you both.
Thank you.
Councilman.
Yeah, I just wanted to add in because I just visit the lighthouse for the blind and just in here you talk about accommodation for special populations and group.
It really touched my heart.
And so so thank you for your leadership and I owe that is an amazing portrait and reflective of your daughter.
I actually got a chance to meet I was daughter at Ponte la Cafe one morning and she's absolutely a doll.
And so great piece of work.
My God, that is amazing.
I think Jerry and I was just talking about it was this phenomenon.
So thank you very much.
Thank you.
All right. Well, thank you both so much.
And we're thrilled and thank you, Mr. Scott, too.
We just love that poster.
It's fantastic.
We have the second order of business a presentation project butterfly Rashida Govan, executive director and founder participants.

Hillary Lyons, Dara Nina Davis, Alyssa Moore, Tierra Jones and Logan Butler, explaining how they help girls rediscover the power within themselves and prepare them to transform their transform their lives and lead their communities.
Thank you, Madam Clerk.
I am very excited to welcome a very special person, executive director Rashida Govan and a very special organization, Project Butterfly to the Floor.
Project Butterfly serves more than 200 young ladies here in the city of New Orleans.
It helps them to discover and sometimes rediscover the power within and also prepare them to transform their lives as well as the lives of their community by leading.
Ms. Govan, organizations like yours are integral, in my opinion, because they help us accomplish one of the most important things that we as a city can do.
And that is helping mold and develop our young people into the leaders they can be.
In 2008, Ms. Govan had the opportunity to intern at the Urban League.
I remember that.
And ever since then, she has just been figuring out different ways in this community to dig in, to work hard and to lead by example and to help others become leaders.
So I just want to turn it over to you.
Thank you. Good morning, everyone.
I'm Dr. Rashida Govan and I am the executive director and founder of Project Butterfly New Orleans.
And I'm really proud to introduce you to our girls.
We are an African Center Girls' Rights of Passage program, which simply means that we are preparing girls of African descent for their transition from adolescence to adulthood.
So how we do that is through a number of ways.
But before I go into it, I want to let the girls introduce themselves.
Hi, I am Logan Butler.
I'm a senior at Benjamin Franklin High School.
Good morning.
I am Tiara Jones and I am a junior at Benjamin Franklin High School.
Good morning.
I'm Hillary Lyons and I'm a junior at the International High School.
Good morning.
I am Alyssa Moore and I am a senior at Benjamin Franklin High School.
Good morning, everyone.
I'm Darianna Davis and I'm a senior at the International High School of New Orleans.
Welcome, ladies.
Welcome.
So we're going to try to keep this quick because I got to take them back to school.
But the program, as I said, was established in 2009 and since then we've served 200 girls.
We partner with College Track as well as the Urban League to execute our program.
So we have girls on the West Bank at Landry Walker and then we have our girls at the College Track Center.
Some of the ways that we do our work are to provide weekly safe spaces for girls to talk about issues that are pertinent to them,
such as media literacy, healthy and positive relationships, healthy decision-making habits, leadership development, things along those lines.
And we also do monthly programs, which you can see a list of them.
There are some that seem a little provocative on there.
I'll share with you what the content of those are in a few.
But the one that we're here to really talk about is our Having Our Say policy document.
So Having Our Say is a book that was written by two centenarians, the Delaney sisters,
that talked about their experiences through their lifetime.
And so we borrowed that title to really talk about why it is important to lift up the voices of young people who are typically silenced.
And so the girls are going to talk to you today about our Having Our Say policy platform for African American girls and women.
This is a policy platform they created on their own with some support from us.
And these are some pictures of how they executed that.
So they spent a lot of time digging in and learning about the issues.
They then kind of looked at how it impacts the whole woman and their families.
And then as you can see, like, post-it notes and then working in small groups,
that's the way that they begin to unpack these issues and then identify recommendations and strategies to address them.
And so they're going to tell you about their points of view and about the policies they think that we should move forward.
Good morning.
Today I will be discussing criminal justice.
Criminal justice is a very important issue in our community.
People mostly focus criminal justice around boys and men,
and the impact that it has on African American girls and women, it goes often overlooked.
As I present this, keep in mind that African American women only represent 13 percent of U.S. women.
But despite this, African American women represent 53.4 percent of women stopped by police.
More than 22 percent of women killed by police in 2015 were African American women.
African American girls are two times more likely to be incarcerated than our white counterparts.
And African American girls and women also experience racial profiling and higher rates of police brutality.
Ways to address these issues African American girls and women face daily.
We as Better Flies in Training propose that you, one, establish a commission to examine criminal justice issues
that African American girls and women face because many people don't know and it is never a crime to educate.
We also should definitely work to replace school suspensions with support groups, mental health services,
and leadership opportunities to African American girls and other students.
Lastly, we propose to provide educators with professional development to stop the school to prison pipeline
for black girls and other students of color.
Examples would be implicit bias training and training in restorative justice, which have both proven to be very effective.
Hello. I will be delving into the importance of economic development among African American women.
The lives of African American girls and women are heavily impacted by their economic status.
The lack of a stable income sets a negative trend among black families and it heavily impacts their children.
There are multiple factors that increase Louisiana's percentage of impoverished African American women.
In terms of pay, African American women are paid 47 cents per every dollar that their white male co-worker can make.
52% of African American families are headed by black women, making it much more difficult for these women to take care of their children.
And oftentimes they're deprived of the same opportunities that other kids would have.
In addition to this, 60% of black families are poor or working poor,
which means that they often cannot afford the necessities such as food, shelter, water, clothing, and most importantly, safety.
So to rectify these problems, my fellow butterflies and I have come up with a few solutions.
We should advocate for women's wage equity laws to prevent them from being underpaid.
In addition to this, we should raise minimum wage to a livable wage to decrease the number of impoverished families.
Also, we have all agreed that it would be a very good idea to create and fund programs that educate, mentor, and support African American girls and women to pursue entrepreneurship.
Good morning. Once again, I'm Hillary Lyons, and I'm here to talk about injustices in the educational system in New Orleans.
One issue in low-income public high schools like the one that I attend is that we don't have college readiness courses such as calculus, pre-calculus, physics, and other rigorous AP courses.

This impacts us when we take college readiness exams such as the ACT or the SAT because since we haven't taken those type of courses, we don't score as high on those exams, forcing us not to be able to fully reach our educational potential.
Additionally, in the classes that we are offered, we are taught by teachers with very little or no teaching experience.
And this directly impacts us because teachers who are very inexperienced won't necessarily know how to teach students, especially students in environments that they aren't used to.
Finally, as Logan mentioned earlier, African American girls are more likely to be suspended from school.
Using this way of discipline to combat student conflicts is very ineffective in my opinion because when students are suspended, they aren't only isolated from their peers.
They are isolated from their peers and instead of being taught of ways to deal with their conflicts.

To remedy these issues, me and my fellow butterflies recommend that you recruit, train, and retain experienced teachers, train teachers to deal with traumatic situations involving students, and create and enforce college readiness courses for the students.
Good morning. I'm Melissa Moore and today I want to talk about the significant disparities black women and girls experience in their health outcomes.

I was screened kids across the city and an overwhelming majority of the girls are black. Based on the data shared girls who are primarily black were more likely to exhibit higher symptoms of depression, PTSD, and suicidality in comparison to their male counterparts.

This tells us that black girls need mental health support. The stereotype that black girls have attitudes could be a misinterpretation of a sign of trauma and this limits the care and mental health support they need.

According to the data, the rate of black girls with chlamydia were 4.7 times the rate for white girls. In 2016, 4,560 black girls and women received an HIV diagnosis compared to 1,450 white and 1,168 Hispanic girls and women.
This is an alarming difference in numbers seeing that black girls and women make up a smaller portion of the population.
The data shows that black girls and women are not being educated on sex and how to avoid STDs.

Some suggestions for these issues would be to make health care services more accessible and more affordable, to create health care guidelines for health care providers to routinely screen for mental health issues, and to have mandated comprehensive sex education in schools that allows open dialogues and contains neutral facts that educate, not frighten.
Good morning everyone, I'm Darianna Davis, as I said, and I want to begin my portion of the presentation with a quote.
I know the streets, I know the system, I know poverty, and I know how it feels to be 15 and not have a safe place to go.
Affordable housing in New Orleans is not just an issue.
It's a crisis because 61.3% of renters pay 30% or more of their income on rent.
Furthermore, home loan denier rates for black people are twice that of white people.
Not to mention, if they were to receive a loan, they still have to pay an outrageous mortgage.
To combat these issues, we, as butterflies in training, suggest eliminating barriers to financial assistance.
We also would like for you all to turn the many blighted, abandoned homes in New Orleans into affordable homes for black families.
Lastly, we recommend eliminating discriminatory policies towards returning citizens.
If a black person returning to the community from prison does not pose an immediate threat on their surroundings, they should not be denied public housing.
And so I want to thank y'all for rocking. I'm proud of you.
I want to just ask you to continue to provide us with support. We are a very small operation.
We are funded by small donations and just support. Jade is in the room and she's been a supporter.
There are other folks. College Track has been a great partner, but we would like you to support, and the ways that you support, can support, are plentiful.
First, your criminal justice committee can actually center at least some parts of its discussion on the impact of the criminal justice system on African American girls and women.
You already have partnerships and have relationships with Daughters Beyond Accarceration, Women With a Vision, and other organizations to that, or Operation Restoration as well.
We recommend that you have them at the table. We would love to join them as well, just to talk about the impact of the criminal justice system on African American girls and women.
Also, we are really happy and grateful that you have pushed for wage equity here in New Orleans, and ask that you continue to push that policy issue.
And hopefully you can use that influence that you have at the state level as well, because this is going to be an uphill battle.
We also would like you to partner with OPSB to try to figure out ways to retain teachers, high quality teachers in our city.
The affordability of housing can impact people's decisions to stay, and just we want to make sure that people have a really strong quality of life, and you play a part in that.
And partnering with OPSB to sort through what can be done in partnership will be very helpful.

Also, we ask that you use your influence and relationships with the health department and the public health and health industry, healthcare industry, to try to increase access to mental health services and screenings for youth, particularly African American girls.
And then, two more things. We want you to think about with your affordable housing policy actions. Think about the fact that African Americans' median income is around $25,000.
So when you look at the median income in the city, it's somewhere in the neighborhood of $40,000, or something a little bit higher than that.

The fact of the matter is, if you use that median income to set your policies to help achieve greater access to affordable housing, it still could potentially keep African American families from accessing affordable housing.
So please just consider that. And finally, you can endorse this policy if you feel like it's in line with your positions by visiting this website, and you all have it.
If you want to learn more about our work, oh, thank you. And thank you, thank you, Council Member, excuse me, Council Member President. I'm getting a mess, sorry.
I always just call him Jason, I'm sorry.
That works, that works.

Thank you for having us. We've been really excited to come. This is a very big deal. It is very important to me that our girls see women also in leadership, and that's important, so I want to give it up to you all.
A shout out to the ladies in the back who are going to be recognized next.
I want to, though, ask you to check us out at ProjectButterflyNola.org, and also invite you to be in attendance this Saturday.

We have a program called the Mama Monologues at the Ace Hotel from three to five, and it is a performance by mentors and other supporters where they tell stories from their childhood, from their teenage experiences to help the girls to understand that there's a light at the end of the tunnel.

We've been where you are currently, and so we invite you to be there. Jade is performing, excuse it. Erika McConaughey is performing. Judge Love is performing, so this should be really wonderful. So I really encourage you to come, and thank you.
Ladies, this wasn't just good, this wasn't just a job well done. Each and every one of you was brilliant.
You dealt with very difficult topics that we struggle with a lot, but you came at it from a completely different approach with solutions, and I just think it's absolutely brilliant.

commission's decision of conceptual approval of a second floor addition to the 1830s rear kitchen building. This approval allows demolition of the green rated portions of the building in order to add an approximately two hundred fifty square foot unit with an exterior staircase.
For property located at one thousand five to one thousand nine St. Philip Street.

Good morning. Good morning. Good morning. Rene Burgoyne architectural historian here in place of Brian Block our director. I have Aaron vote with us and Nick Albrecht both plans examiners on these two properties.

This is an appeal of the VU commission conceptual approval of a second floor addition with balcony above a rear dependency building. The small existing single story outbuilding has varying ratings and VCC records.

The property report listed as orange unrated 20th century construction while the VCC digital library VCC color map and historic ones collection survey listed as orange green hybrid green rating means of local historical importance.
The survey states the service building which is partially 20th century construction is all the remains of a circa 1830 frame Creole cottage demolished in the 1840s.

The building was partially rebuilt circa 1940 presumably after a fire most likely leaves using some of those original materials staff has inspected the building and noted historic brick on the rear and side walls as well as the chimney all of which will remain intact under the under the current proposal.

The entire front St. Philip side wall is of 20th century construction using much younger brick and will also remain intact the ceiling Joyce are older in appearance staff inspected the attic and does not find the floor the roof framing to be of historic or architectural significance.
Although obviously of old materials ceiling and roof Joyce are not within the VCC jurisdiction as they are interior.

This combination of 19th century remnants and 20th century construction is a reason for the hybrid rating and determination by VCC staff and the architectural committee that the proposal for modification is worthy of consideration.
Although the appellant has claimed that this building is of extreme historic and architectural importance there is little evidence to back up that claim.

According to the VCC design guidelines the approach for an addition to an existing building is guided by the architectural and historical importance of the property as identified by its color rating recognizing that what might be appropriate to one property is not necessarily appropriate at another the VCC does not mandate specific design solutions.
When determining the appropriateness of an addition the VCC is guided by the secretary of interior standards and the general design principles outlined in the guidelines.
And I quote if appropriately designed an addition to an existing building can provide increased space while maintaining the historic character of the original building and landscape streetscape.
When constructing an addition the property owner is encouraged to consider the integrity of the existing building and its color rating.
In spite of the differences between individual properties the VCC residential streetscapes have a cohesive architectural vocabulary.
Buildings have similar scale form mass floor height set back side yards floor and ceiling heights and materials irrespective of building type or architectural style.
Recognizing this cohesion a building addition in a residential block should work within the properties context to maintain the historic ambiance with sympathetic and compatible design at scale.
VCC staff and AC worked with the applicant to bring the proposal into these parameters.
VCC design guidelines for additions list 10 principles to consider during review of proposed work including scale building form and massing setback orientation for solid proportions and details.
According to the guidelines it is generally appropriate to construct an addition with similar form and massing to the existing building and buildings on adjacent sites.
It is also appropriate to construct roof forms that are similar to those found on the existing buildings and the block of the proposed addition.
It is appropriate to install a new architectural element or projection such as a balcony towards the rear of a property.
Staff finds that the proposal meets most of these principles.
The massing building and roof forms are similar to the outbuildings of the adjacent property owned by the appellant.

A timeline of the project review has been provided to all council members and their staff outlining how the project architect has responded well to the comments from staff and from our architecture committee as well as to the concerns of the adjacent neighbors.
In response to committee and staff recommendations the applicant revised several elements of the proposal and provided massing perspectives for review.
These were also provided to council members and staff.

The overall height of the proposed addition was actually lowered to better fit the massing of the buildings on the site next door and a previously proposed gallery was actually omitted and reduced to a rather small balcony to minimize its impact on the site.
The applicant was unable to relocate the stair to the interior of the small building but has further reduced its footprint and provided staff with a precedent of a similar stairs from the district.
The staircase has actually been relocated to the center of the property to address privacy concerns of the adjacent property owner.

Although the appellant has a similar two story addition with a balcony and views into the property that we're discussing, they have expressed concern that should this addition be constructed their privacy would be compromised.

It should be noted that although such privacy issues are taken into account during reviews of this nature, such matters do not preclude appropriate new construction which complies to VCC guidelines, building and city codes and city ordinances.
Buildings within this dense urban environment often have viewsheds into adjacent properties.
For example, the viewsheds from the appellant's house and dependency have historically overlooked the property in question.
At the committee's request, the applicant included more context and drawings of the proposed addition as well as perspectives from the right of way.
These drawings give a better sense of the limited visual impact that the addition will have from the public views.
Staff also noted that the existing sweet olive tree will remain in this courtyard.
As this is an evergreen tree, it will likely serve to block visibility of the proposed new construction from the street, which could address some of the concerns of certain members of the public.
The property owner has assured the committee that this tree will remain.

Once again, VCC guidelines on new construction additions list ten principles to consider during review of proposed work, including scale, building form, mass setback, orientation, facade proportions and details.
Staff notes that any additions or alterations to existing historic buildings must be carefully considered by the committee and commission but are not prohibited by the VCC design guidelines.

On the addition, the Architectural Committee worked with the architects to modify the original plans in a way that eventually led to a conceptual approval.
The architects have reduced the massing, reworked exterior stairs, lowered the height, and reduced the plans for a gallery to a smaller balcony.

It's very evident that as these plans have changed, they've modeled it on the Appellant's house, which is adjacent, which is right next door, the property is right next door, and that outbuilding will mimic that building as well.
The VCC has clearly reviewed the project in accordance with the guidelines and made this conceptual approval, which is only for the second floor addition, in light of those guidelines.
This is the VCC's area of expertise, and where I don't see they've run afoul of their own guidelines, I can't supplant their careful analysis in judgment with my own.
For that reason, I'm going to move to deny the appeal, upholding the VCC's decision of conceptual approval.
But hopefully we all realize that this is only the conceptual approval of the project.
The architect will still be submitting design development drawings to the Architectural Committee for more review and approval.
After that, more detailed construction drawings must be reviewed by the Architectural Committee and or staff prior to the permitting.
Is that correct?
So I do hope that the neighbors stay engaged and involved in this process.

With that, I would also like to state that more generally, Ms. Walensky has made several suggestions to my staff about ways to improve oversight and engagement on projects like this in the French Quarter.
These are things like requiring more notice to neighbors, which I've asked my staff to look into, and more coordination with the Vucaré Commission.
And so I want to thank you for those, they have validity to that, and my team is going to work with that to ensure that that happens.
So, thank you all again for being here.
With that, I move to deny the appeal and uphold the VCC's conceptual approval.
I have a second by Councilmember Nguyen.
Please vote your machines.
Seven yeas, no nays.
Thank you.
